text.text: Welcome to the WWDC22 Object & Room Capture Digital Lounge! We’ve got an exciting week planned for you. You can find the full schedule of events in the <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=53w84172| Apple Developer app and on developer.apple.com>, and activities for all lounges kick off on June 7.
If you haven't already, please take a moment to familiarize yourself with <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=735utu4s|how the Digital Lounges will work>.

We want to make sure these spaces are helpful and welcoming for everyone — developers and Apple employees alike. Please review and follow the <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/policies/interactive-events/1/Apple-Developer-WWDC22-Interactive-Events-Attendance-Policy.pdf| WWDC22 Interactive Events Policy>.

messages.text:
Hi everyone! Welcome to the Object Capture and RoomPlan channel. We’re so happy to have you all here! My name is Thorsten and I’m an Engineering Manager for Object Capture.

We are very excited to share the session videos with the updates for <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10128/|Object Capture> and the introduction of <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10127/|RoomPlan>. Please take a look.

We will start the activities in this channel today at 3pm PST with the digital lounge for Object Capture.

messages.text: <@U03J7GGBZDW> added a workflow to this channel: *Object Capture - Ask a Question*.

<@U03J20E7UBV> asked
> Hi!  I'm just wondering if you have suggested guidance for capturing objects that are on a rotating platform, to minimize post-production work.  Is it advised to try to frame the platform out of the image as best as possible, to post-process each image and crop out the platform, wrap the platform in a similar color to the background, etc.?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hi!  I'm just wondering if you have suggested guidance for capturing objects that are on a rotating platform, to minimize post-production work.  Is it advised to try to frame the platform out of the image as best as possible, to post-process each image and crop out the platform, wrap the platform in a similar color to the background, etc.?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
We suggest to use a uniform color platform which is different than the object and keep the object inside the frame, but as large as possible. Use object masking to make PhotogrammetrySession remove the background <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/realitykit/photogrammetrysession/configuration-swift.struct/isobjectmaskingenabled>

For difficult objects you can also provide manual masks. Please see  <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/realitykit/photogrammetrysample/objectmask>

messages.text:
<@U03JELHDSS2> asked
> How can I crop the model after it is made?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"How can I crop the model after it is made? "}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
We provide a `Geometry` field on the model reconstruction `Request` that will allow you to specify the cropping region _during_ the model creation step.  We show this flow in last year's WWDC session (<https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10076/>).  To recap, a GUI app can be made with the API that will let you request a preview model, arrange the reconstruction volume, and then get the cropped output.

We recommend cropping during reconstruction since this allows our algorithms to focus the texture and mesh resolution on areas that are being reconstructed.

Also note that this year we added the ability to specify an `OrientedBoundedBox` in the request to allow a more general cropping volume.

messages.text:
<@U03J20E7UBV> asked
> Can you clarify the underlying differences for a `RoomCaptureView` and a `RoomCaptureSession`?  `RoomCaptureView` seems like it is a `UIView` subclass that handles all of the underlying logic for scanning and creation of the 3D model for output, whereas `RoomCaptureSession` appears to be a custom implementation that allows us to customize the process.  What would be the use case for a custom `RoomCaptureSession`?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Can you clarify the underlying differences for a `RoomCaptureView` and a `RoomCaptureSession`?  `RoomCaptureView` seems like it is a `UIView` subclass that handles all of the underlying logic for scanning and creation of the 3D model for output, whereas `RoomCaptureSession` appears to be a custom implementation that allows us to customize the process.  What would be the use case for a custom `RoomCaptureSession`?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
`RoomCaptureView` is a plug and play view that you can use in your app
`RoomCaptureSession` let’s you subscribe to updates using a delegate and gives you finer grain control over the surfaces and objects that RoomPlan detects.
RoomCapture session can be used for filtering out surfaces or objects and rendering them as per your liking.

*What new features would you like to see for object capture?*

slackdump_thread_replies.text: can do object capture on iPad and iPhone.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: NeRF support - so we'll be able to capture Reflective/Shiny/Glossy objects aswell.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
I'd love to see;
• Support for processing/creating models on iPadOS in addition to macOS.
• A first-class UI for modifying a bounding box around the captured model, similar to how Room Plan has a RoomCaptureView, so we do not have to implement our own bounding box and gestures to refine the model's geometry area.
• The ability to have some sort of combination of Object Capture and Room Plan; allowing to not only capture the geometry of a room or space, but texture it, as well.
Also, Room Plan and Object Capture are incredible and game changes.  Their existence, and the Photogrammetry API ease of use, is going to open the door to so many new ideas and industries.  The team has done a great, great job on this!

>                         didEndWith data: CapturedRoomData, error: Error?)` method, just prior to exporting to a USDZ model, or at some other time during the capture process?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"If someone were interested in filtering out [.objects] from a captured RoomPlan, would it be advised to do this in the `func captureSession(_ session: RoomCaptureSession, \n                        didEndWith data: CapturedRoomData, error: Error?)` method, just prior to exporting to a USDZ model, or at some other time during the capture process?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Another excellent question. It would be great to have you join us at the RoomPlan Q&A session tomorrow where we can cover this and lots of other questions on this topic.

It all depends if you’re using `RoomCaptureView` or not: if you are, there’s no way of filtering out objects from live scan rendering, so you’ll have to do it prior to exporting to a USDZ. If you have your own custom view (using Data Only API), We’d recommend doing it directly in the live view (so that end users understand that objects won’t be part of the final USDZ)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Both `CapturedRoom` and `CapturedRoomData` are read-only. `CapturedRoomData` is intended for generating the final room model with `RoomBuilder.` During capture, you can parse the `CapturedRoom` structures and add your custom visualization (eg. photorealist chairs, fantastical objects as you mentioned) on the real world.

<@U03J1UXFUKV> asked
> Hi all, super stoked to watch the RoomPlan session yesterday. I am quite new to ARKit and the USD filetype so forgive me if this question is out of scope for this session. What would be the best way to create a 2D floor-plan (image) from the outputted USD file on-device? We've got ways we could do this on our servers, but the ability to process this on device would be amazing.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hi all, super stoked to watch the RoomPlan session yesterday. I am quite new to ARKit and the USD filetype so forgive me if this question is out of scope for this session. What would be the best way to create a 2D floor-plan (image) from the outputted USD file on-device? We've got ways we could do this on our servers, but the ability to process this on device would be amazing."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
USD file contains 3D dimension and transformation information. Therefore, you could do projection to 2D in any arbitrary angle.
For 2D floorplan, simply projection from y coordinate should work.

elements.text:
USD file contains 3D dimension and transformation information. Therefore, you could do projection to 2D in any arbitrary angle.
For 2D floorplan, simply projection from y coordinate should work.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Alex, are the dimensions available directly from the USD file? Is there sample code for this?
yes, dimensions are inside usdz file. You could import the exported usdz. I think you could find more info in documentation.

elements.text: yes, dimensions are inside usdz file. You could import the exported usdz. I think you could find more info in documentation.

<@U03K7271MEC> asked
> is the accuracy of the RoomPlan the same level of accuracy as the LiDAR scan? aside from the known issue with the scale being 100 times off, how much difference is it from real scale when scaled back appropriately when it's exported from USDZ to FBX or OBJ.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"is the accuracy of the RoomPlan the same level of accuracy as the LiDAR scan? aside from the known issue with the scale being 100 times off, how much difference is it from real scale when scaled back appropriately when it's exported from USDZ to FBX or OBJ."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We are constantly working on improving the accuracy of the RoomPlan results. RoomPlan is intended for simplified parametric representation of the room. It does not have the same level of accuracy as LiDAR scans. We do have a lot to improve to support applications that have high accuracy requirement.

elements.text: We are constantly working on improving the accuracy of the RoomPlan results. RoomPlan is intended for simplified parametric representation of the room. It does not have the same level of accuracy as LiDAR scans. We do have a lot to improve to support applications that have high accuracy requirement.

messages.text:
<@U03K6CZC8LQ> asked
> Are the RoomPlan models as accurate as the ARMeshAnchors or is accuracy being sacrificed for clean geometry?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Are the RoomPlan models as accurate as the ARMeshAnchors or is accuracy being sacrificed for clean geometry?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We haven’t compared the accuracy between RoomPlan models with ARMeshAnchors. A RoomPlan model is intended to be a simplified parametric representation of the room. We are trying to make the final model to be as close to the real world as possible. But there are some abstractions or simplifications such as representing wall/window/door/opening as planes without thickness.

elements.text: We haven’t compared the accuracy between RoomPlan models with ARMeshAnchors. A RoomPlan model is intended to be a simplified parametric representation of the room. We are trying to make the final model to be as close to the real world as possible. But there are some abstractions or simplifications such as representing wall/window/door/opening as planes without thickness.

Using RealityKit you can load the USDZ as an Entity and then perform evaluations on it. Please note that there is a known issue with Beta 1 on the scale of dimensions in a USDZ file.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Extend an existing scan. Multiple floors. Handle odd angles and non-flat ceilings. Stairs. Extract a floor plan in some useful hopefully standard format for that. Ditch USD as it’s not intended for this.

elements.text: Extend an existing scan. Multiple floors. Handle odd angles and non-flat ceilings. Stairs. Extract a floor plan in some useful hopefully standard format for that. Ditch USD as it’s not intended for this.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Would love the ability to reuse an ARSession across multiple RoomPlan sessions, or for other uses before and after the RoomCaptureSession.

By allowing a consistent coordinate system, this would help provide experiences in captured rooms after capturing them; provide other scanning capabilities such as scanning object textures; or make it easier to combine multiple adjacent rooms.

This could even follow a pattern consistent with that introduced by the new NearbyInteraction NISession.setARSession added in iOS 16. They achieve this by documenting explicit rules about the configuration and use of ARSessions supplied to the NISession.

elements.text:
Would love the ability to reuse an ARSession across multiple RoomPlan sessions, or for other uses before and after the RoomCaptureSession.

By allowing a consistent coordinate system, this would help provide experiences in captured rooms after capturing them; provide other scanning capabilities such as scanning object textures; or make it easier to combine multiple adjacent rooms.

This could even follow a pattern consistent with that introduced by the new NearbyInteraction NISession.setARSession added in iOS 16. They achieve this by documenting explicit rules about the configuration and use of ARSessions supplied to the NISession.

<@U03J22LUULS> asked
> On Full Reconstruction Displacement maps always turn out Red. They are about 100MB large but contain no useable data. I checked all the different Color channels

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"On Full Reconstruction Displacement maps always turn out Red. They are about 100MB large but contain no useable data. I checked all the different Color channels"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
In the _full_ detail level we provide the following texture maps: _diffuse, normal, AO, roughness, displacement_. Displacement is useful for some use cases.

In case you do not need some of the texture maps you could try to output uncompressed USDA and individual texture maps in a folder (by providing a folder URL). That makes it easier to choose a subset of the texture maps.

elements.text: detail level we provide the following texture maps:

. Displacement is useful for some use cases.

In case you do not need some of the texture maps you could try to output uncompressed USDA and individual texture maps in a folder (by providing a folder URL). That makes it easier to choose a subset of the texture maps.

messages.text:
<@U03J22LUULS> asked
> Can we use a Bounding Box on the PointCloud to pass to PhotogrammetrySession before starting mesh reconstruction to cut down on time for reconstruction?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Can we use a Bounding Box on the PointCloud to pass to PhotogrammetrySession before starting mesh reconstruction to cut down on time for reconstruction? "}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
The `.bounds` `Request` should be used to get the initial reconstruction bounding box.  This can be used in an GUI iterative workflow as shown in the WWDC 21 Object Capture video to then send the desired reconstruction volume box for the reconstruction to use by adding it into the `Geometry` property of the `Request`.

Note that this year we added `OrientedBoundingBox` to allow more general reconstruction boxes (not axis-aligned).  We recommend to use the `.preview` `Detail` along with `.bounds` for this, but it should also be possible to use the point cloud as well.  The key is that the volume specified in `Geometry` is relative to the initial coordinate system defined by the `.bounds` `Request`.

Intermediate results in the session are cached, so subsequent requests should be faster than the initial ones as well.

messages.text:
<@U03J20E7UBV> asked
> Is there a way to feed a folder of images and masks to the Photogrammetry API, or will I need to instantiate each image and mask individually?  I know I can provide a folder, I just wasn’t sure if there is a way for the API to know which images are masks.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is there a way to feed a folder of images and masks to the Photogrammetry API, or will I need to instantiate each image and mask individually?  I know I can provide a folder, I just wasn\u2019t sure if there is a way for the API to know which images are masks."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
The `PhotogrammetrySession` when provided with a folder will assume _all_ image files in the folder are RGB images of the object to be reconstructed, so you cannot mix them all in one folder if you use the folder input init.  There is currently not a way to specify masks using the folder input to a session.

To provide masks, you will need to use the custom input `PhotogrammetrySession` that takes a lazy sequence of `PhotogrammetrySample`objects that you create yourself in your app.  You will have to load the images yourself in this case and they can be stored whereever you wish, in the same folder, in a database, etc.

that takes a lazy sequence of
objects that you create yourself in your app.  You will have to load the images yourself in this case and they can be stored whereever you wish, in the same folder, in a database, etc.

<@U03J20E7UBV> asked
> If "object masking" is enabled when processing a Photogrammetry model, but there are no object masks provided, does the algorithm create its own mask?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"If \"object masking\" is enabled when processing a Photogrammetry model, but there are no object masks provided, does the algorithm create its own mask?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: yes if this value is enabled, but the samples don’t contain object masks, Object Capture attempts to automatically create a mask algorithmically. If it’s unable to create a mask, Object Capture reverts to reconstructing the object using the entire image.

elements.text: yes if this value is enabled, but the samples don’t contain object masks, Object Capture attempts to automatically create a mask algorithmically. If it’s unable to create a mask, Object Capture reverts to reconstructing the object using the entire image.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can use `transform` and `dimensions` paremeters to draw lines. The 4 corners can be inferred from those 2 parameters: the first column of the transform is the "right" vector, and second is the "up" vector. The fourth column is the position of the wall/door/opening/window/object Combining those unit vectors with the dimensions vector will give you the corners
